To reduce waste, resist the temptation of holiday-themed paper plates.
Use dishwasher-friendly plates instead, says Dale Bryk of the Natural Resources Defense Council, and don't waste water by rinsing every last bit of cranberry sauce off.
Even though your mother may have told you, like mine did, you got to wash all the plates before you put them in the dishwasher, that really is not necessary anymore.
We have much better dishwashers than we did back in the '70s.

Suicides in the Army rose last year for the third straight time.
The Army said today that there were 99 suicides in 2006.
About a third of those took place in Iraq or Afghanistan.
NPR's Tom Bowman reports.
The Army has seen a fairly steady hike in the rate of suicides among soldiers.
There were about 17 suicides per 100,000 soldiers.
That's the highest rate in 26 years in a jump of more than 6 percent from 2004.
Colonel Elspeth Ritchie, who works for the Army Surgeon General, was asked by reporters if there was a link between combat and the increased suicide rate.
What we have found is not a direct relationship so far between deployment, combat and suicide.
However, we do know that frequent deployments put a real strain on relationships especially on marriages.
And the Army researchers say that it is a failed relationship - often the result of extensive time overseas - that can spur suicides.
Again, Colonel Ritchie.
Most suicides in our Army population are impulsive acts.
Very often a young soldier gets a Dear John or Dear Jane e-mail and then takes his weapon and shoots himself.
That strain is particularly hard on younger soldiers.
The Army found that the typical suicide is a white male, between 21 and 30 years old, with a rank of private or specialist serving in the infantry.
And Colonel Ritchie says Army officials fear that even longer deployments could make the situation worse.
In April, the Army increased the combat deployment time to 15 months in Iraq or Afghanistan, before then it was 12 months.
We are seeing a lot of strained or failed relationships and our typical both attempt and completion is after the breakup of a relationship.
Of the 99 suicides in 2006, 27 took place in Iraq and three were in Afghanistan.
And Army officials say that year there were 948 attempted suicides both overseas and at home.
This is only the second year that the Army has looked at attempted suicides, attempts that were serious enough to result in a trip to the hospital.
And what is the army doing to reverse this trend?
Hiring more mental health counselors, teaching soldiers in the field to look for the warning signs of posttraumatic stress and other mental disorders and providing more help to families.
Colonel Dennis Dingle, another Army officer who've talked about the reports' results, says additional time off for soldiers is necessary.
Now, that soldiers are serving 15-month tours, the Army has just increased their break period from 15 days to 18 days.
We recognize that soldiers that are on the ground longer should have some additional respite from their tour, and that's a recent change that just went into effect.
But a recent report by a Pentagon mental health survey team said combat soldiers need even more time off.
It said that soldiers who face heavy combat should get 30 days off for every 90 days in combat.
Tom Bowman, NPR News, Washington.
